channel.title: MyRightCareer
channel.description: Helping you find your Right Career

item.title: Old Full Instructions - Autobiography
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the Autobiography Exercise

Click on the link above to see a video where Don describes the Autobiography concept and explains your Exercise via some examples. If you would like to have a copy of the presentation in front of you while viewing the video you can click on PowerPoint File (pdf) to view a pdf version of the PowerPoint file used during the video presentation. You can then view, print or download the file. At the conclusion of the video close the Windows Media Player, then close the page it was running in and you will return to this page.

Introduction

In this exercise you need to: 1) Write an autobiography & provide insights, 2) Document the transitions & provide insights, 3) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights document the insights you have gained from this exercise, 4) Provide feedback, 5) Discuss the exercise with your Facilitator and 6) Become an example.
In Step 4 you will be asked for your Feedback. If you want to look at the Survey, without actually taking it, click on Autobiography Survey - pdf version. You may want to do this so you can see, before you start the exercise, the types of questions you will be asked to answer after completing the exercise. Don't use this to provide feedback.

Autobiography Approach

So quickly what you are doing is looking back at your life to see if you can gain any insights that will help you identify what you want to do going forward. You will be doing this by documenting your life in a short Autobiography, in outline format. You will then look at all the Transitions you have made in your life. Using both of these you will look at the insights you can draw.

Your Assignment

Now you get to put these concepts into play for your life. It works best if you print out these instructions and then use the Web site while looking at the printed instructions.

Resources to help you

Examples:One of the best ways to do this exercise is to look at how others have done the exercise. There is an exercise from Don in all of the Assignments and it is the most complete exercise. You do not have to have your exercise be as complete as his, but it is useful as an example. The other examples are more representative of what a typical college student would do. The examples can be found on the Autobiography Examples page in the Sub Navigation section on the right hand side of this page.
Templates: There is a Word template for the Autobiography document. It can be found on the Autobiography Templates page in the Sub Navigation section on the right hand side of this page. The other documents don't require templates.
Video & Presentation: For those of you who learn better by listening to a presentation, instead of reading instructions, you can watch the Welcome to the Autobiography Exercise video again. You might want a hard copy of the presentation in front of you so you can make notes on it. The Welcome to the Autobiography Exercise Video is about 5 minutes long so it will not take long to review it again. You can pause at any point and back up if necessary. You can find both of them at the top of this page: - Video: you can click on the Welcome to the Autobiography Exercise Video link at any time to listen & view the video again. - Presentation: you can click on the PowerPoint file link to view, print or download the pdf version of the PowerPoint file at any time.

  • 1) Write an Autobiography and Provide Insights

    • Autobiography Structure

    Here are some elements I would like you to use, but you are free to do this anyway you find easiest. Click on Casey's Autobiography to see an example of an Autobiography. It follows the recommended structure. - Use an Outline format. Generally you don't need to use more than one line to describe each item, e.g. "Father quit Caterpillar and bought Varna Heating & Electric"; Merging our 13 kids with Lacon's 27 kids to make our 7th grade; Winning State Baseball Championship; Being in the Junior Play; Mr. Waxler said I should be an engineer so I went to Rose Poly. You are not writing this so someone else can read it. You know there is a story behind each of those one line statements. When you get famous you can use this as the outline for your Autobiography and then you (or your ghost writer) can write the prose that will let the rest of us understand your life. With Word you can have as many levels of indentation as you want if that helps communicate meaning. - Have a separate page for each element of your Life Framework. Casey's has a page for Ancestors, a page for Elementary through High School and a page for College. This lets you work on them separately – adding, deleting and changing material. - Keep your Personal and Professional elements separate. For example in Don's he has a Personal - College and a Professional - College. You could just put everything in Personal but it will help you later identifying your Right Career by having a Professional category. Examples of items that are in Don's "Professional - College" are: Summer Job at Detroit Edison, Founding College Newspaper and Managing construction of Fraternity Homecoming Display.

    Autobiography Approach

    Here is a tops down approach for writing your autobiography: - High Level First, start with a high level version. Don’t try to put down detail until you get the overall structure in place. Now you have an outline and can fill in details. This is the way writing coaches suggest a book be written.
    - Family: Parents, Siblings - Elementary School, Middle School (6th, 7th & 8th), High School (9th, 10th, 11th & 12th) - College: Freshman, Sophomore, Junior, Senior - Put in some Detail Second, put in some detail so you have the start of your autobiography, e.g. on the professional side you want some detail below high school and college, while on the personal side you may want to have some level of personal detail on all of them. - Drill Down Third, pick a few areas and drill down in them. You will gain insights just by what areas you choose to dive down into (they show your interests). This is not about writing down everything that has happened in your life. - Summary: You probably don’t want to have the same level of detail for every area. In the past one mistake I have seen people make is just starting to write and running out of steam about half way through. They ended up with way too much detail on the early parts of their life. One person did an elaborate history of their very large family and then later realized it was not really very valuable. In retrospect they realized it was not going to be valuable but they found writing the history very interesting.

    Autobiography Insights

    Here are are different ways to help you gain some insights into your autobiography.

    Look for Themes

    Below are some different ways of gaining insights from your autobiography taken from the book "What Now" by Laura Fortgang: Take a look at any "Golden Threads" that may run through your life, e.g. - Interests, e.g. environment, politics, technology - Kinds of roles, e.g. leader, follower, avoid getting involved - Cultures, e.g. small organizations, large organizations, non profits - Behavior, e.g. left tasks/groups/classes just as they got challenging, stayed put rather than take a risk, looking for next challenge - Lack of an element, e.g. lack of leadership (always behind-the-scenes), lack of outside activities (always only academic) See if you have any "Interrupted Dreams", e.g. things you put on hold because of being consumed by academics or sports. Maybe you just never got around to doing it. Examples might be: - Early interest in music - Competition between writing and sports, where sports won Do you have any "Driving Motivators" that are rooted in the past that not longer serve you, e.g. - Susan: worked three times harder than anyone (job, marriage, mother): driven by getting pregnant at 17 & given up college scholarship: Driving Motivator - vowed to beat the odds of not going to college. But she no longer had to prove herself, she had done that long ago. - Tom: give you shirt off his back, gave away his ideas, help people who weren’t ready to change: Driving Motivator – guilt because his family always had everything. He could now realize he did not have to take the responsibility for his family's success. - Mason: everything was because “he should do it” - the message he received from his family all the time. Did he still have to do things because he felt he had to please his family or could he start doing things that meant something to him.

    Try these Prompts

    These are some things to consider
    - Don't Want to Do: If you can't think of anything you want to do, how about thinking of some things you know you don't want to do. Most people can come up with things they don't want to do more easily than they can identify what they want to do. Part of Don's Autobiography was working for four summers with his father as an apprentice plumber and electrician. He also worked on a crew paving country roads one summer. During those 5 years he would work on farms from time to time. He knew he was not good at practical activities and should not pursue a trade. Instead he needed to do some more intellectual.
    - Born to Do: Do you feel compelled to do something because of family traditions or patterns? Harry was raised in a family where both parents were social workers. His father was a Professor of Social Work. He called his mother an idealist who often did things for others. In his definition of what he wanted to do when he was thirty one of the things he said was "I want to do something where I am helping others because it makes me feel positive." He also often organized social outings for others, e.g. ski trips.
    - Others said you should do: Is there a common theme of what others have said you should be doing with your life, e.g. you have the mind of a lawyer, you should use you musical talents, all of the family has gone into medicine? Don was always expected to be the responsible person, the one upon whom the group could depend. Especially in high school he was expected to be the "adult". His mother was a teacher and as the principal said one time "we expect more from you Don". That expectation stayed with him in college.

    Write your Autobiography Insights

    You can write your insights as either a separate document as Don and Casey did.
  • Casey's Autobiography Insights
  • Don's Autobiography Insights
    Or you can incorporate your Insights into your Autobiography by placing them at the end of the document.

  • 2) Document your Major Transitions and Provide Insights

    • You have to decide what qualifies as a major enough Transition to make it in this document. When I think of a major transition I look at the difference between the beginning state (the “from”) and the ending state (the “to”). I see it as major when there is a lot of difference in how you live your life, e.g. - Moving Homes (with your parents): once, twice, more - From home in high end town to college in old inner city - Changing Schools: public elementary to private middle & high school - Changing High School to College: small to large, public to private, private to public - Changing Sports Teams: While in high school, high school to college, while in college - Parents getting Divorced - New Blended Family - Popular to Unpopular - Normal student to Leader - Service worker to internship - Worker to manager

    Transitions & Major Transitions documents

    Here is a simple way to create a Transitions document. Make a copy of your Autobiography and name it XYZ-Transitions.doc. Now go through the document highlighting all of the items in red you feel have been a transition for you. If you believe there have been other Transitions you have not captured with this approach write them at the end of the document. To create a Major Transitions document you take the items you believe to be major and make them Bold. If you now print out a copy of the document you will have your Transitions document, which is your entire Autobiography, with some items in red and others in Bold red. This should provide you with a lot of insights into your life. Click on Casey's Transitions & Insights to see an example of that approach.

    Transition Insights

    You could have made a lot of transitions in your life already, as laid out earlier. Each one of those transitions could provide some insights that could contribute to one of your four MyRightCareer Insights files: - Moving Homes (with your parents): Maybe you have moved several times in your life, what did you learn from that. Maybe you only moved once before going to college, but that was either great or terrible. - From home in high end town to college in old inner city: Unfortunately a lot of the older, very good schools, are "on the wrong side of the tracks". This may be the first time you have not lived in an upscale community. - Changing Schools: Maybe you went from a large public elementary school to a small private middle school. Or from a small private middle school to a large public high school. - Changing Schools: Maybe you went from a large public high school to a huge public college. Or from a small private high school to a private college that is still dramatically larger than your high school. - Changing Sports Teams: Maybe you went from a friendly local soccer team to a competitive college prep team with kids from all over the area. - Changing Sports Teams: Maybe you went from being a star on your club soccer team to being on the bench on your college soccer team. - Parents getting Divorced: Maybe your parents got divorced and your life changed dramatically. - Blended Family: Maybe your divorced mother got remarried and you now have a half sister and half brother around your age. - Popular to Unpopular: Maybe you suddenly were no longer part of the "In" group. - Normal student to Leader: Maybe you became the President of your class and people treated you differently.
    You can write your insights as either a separate document as Don did. Click on Don's Transitions Insights to see how he formatted his Transition insights. What he did was make each of his major Transitions a bullet in the Autobiography outline and then put a insight comment indented below the Major Transition.
    Or you can incorporate your Insights into your Transitions document by placing them at the end of the document as Casey did. She wrote three paragraphs. I realized the major academic transitions have been the hardest for me. I went to an all girls middle school where I had to make new friends and I was only around girls was hard for me to adapt too. Similarity, when I went to my large public high school, I had to transition back to being in a co-ed environment that wasn’t as creative or free as my small private all girls’ middle school. I was lucky to find a great group of girls who I love with all my heart. Both transitions helped me prepare for the biggest one yet, moving all the way to the east coast for college where I only see my family and home friends every few months. It is very different on the east coast and I learned that you have to be outgoing if you want to make friends and meet people. While these transitions have been difficult, they have helped me attain traits which I am most proud of today (my outgoing personality, optimistic attitude, being able to adapt to a new environment).

  • 3) Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

    • If you remember from the previous exercise, Begin at the End, there are four MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine" and one for "Right Opportunity". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story. You have already gained insights from your Autobiography exercise and your Transitions exercise. Below are some Prompts that can generate some more insights around your Autobiography. They should get you thinking about insights from a different angle:

    Casey Examples

    These four documents are examples of the insights Casey added based on the Autobiography exercise. She was able to add a lot of insights by using the material she gained from: - Autobiography itself - Autobiography Insights document - Transitions Insights
    Click on the links below to see Casey's examples - showing her insights from both the Begin at the End and Autobiography exercises:
    Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Opportunity" Insights

    Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

    Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Be sure to add insights to each of the documents: - Be Your Best: From looking at your Autobiography you should have been able to identify some natural strengths and indications of your natural personality. Have you ever dedicated yourself to one activity, e.g. soccer or theater, and become really good at it. Do people tell you that you are outgoing? - Meaning & Passion: You most likely have had some passions in your life as of now. Do you love theater, sports? Are you involved in any political activities. It doesn't mean those are the ones you will have going forward, but it is important to document them. - Fuel your Economic Engine: Can you tell if your current economic standard of living is higher or lower than the one you probably will be able to afford when you are age 30? If your parents live in an expensive home and work in high paying jobs it is doubtful you will be able to do that by age 30. But is that your expectation? Have you worked to pay your expenses or have your parents always paid all your expenses? - Right Opportunities: Maybe you have always wanted to be a jet pilot, Don did. Maybe when you were younger you wanted to be a coach. Even if you don't want to have those as a career now, write them down because they provide some insights into your thinking at that time. Do you have multiple ideas now that you have looked back over your life? They don't have to be realistic or even things that will survive further analysis. Write them down because they provide insights into your thought process.

  • 4) Discuss your Results with Your Facilitator

    • Now it is time again to discuss your results with your Facilitator. You may have been communicating with them along the way, e.g. you might have shared a draft of your Autobiography. But assuming you have not shared anything here are the suggested items to share and discuss:

    Discuss Content Issues

    These first items are content oriented issues:
  • Autobiography Insights: This is a key document to discuss.
  • Autobiography: This is a backup to the Insights. Remember it was not really written to be read so you will probably have to add some context for them.
  • Major Transitions Insights: Another key document to discuss
  • Major Transitions: This is a backup and probably should be shown.
  • MyRightCareer Insights Documents: This is the most important set of documents you have to discuss. You should have taken all of your findings in this exercise and placed them in the right of the four documents. There are four of these - Be Your Best, Meaning/Passion, Economic Engine and Right Opportunities. This is the first time you will have added insights to an existing document so it is important to see how your knowledge is growing.

    Discuss Process Issues

    These last items are process oriented issues:
  • Schedule: You have now done two exercises. You and your Facilitator may want to revise your schedule.
  • Facilitator Review Process: You have just finished your 2nd review, maybe the two of you want to do it differently in the future, or you now have a process that works for both of you.
  • Anything else you want to discuss: Who knows what has come up in doing these two exercises.
    The most important thing for you to discuss are the four MyRightCareer Insights documents. They will form the foundation for the identification of your Right Opportunity in the Capstone Project.

        5) Feedback

        Click on Feedback to access the Feedback page so you can take a survey and provide your feedback on the Autobiography Exercise.
        As we said before I am making changes to the MyRightCareer Program and Web site in almost real time so your timely feedback is very important. Students coming after you will benefit from it.

        Summary

        In the previous exercise, Begin at the End, you should have picked up some insights about your Right Career from visualizing your life at Age 30. This exercise, looking back over your life and your ancestors lives, gives you a different perspective. These two views of your life should give you some insights into what you can “Be Best At - your natural strengths & personality”, what has “Meaning & Passion” for you, what influences your "Economic Engine" and maybe some ideas of what you might find interesting (or found in the past) as your Right Career.

item.title: Adviser Guidance-AutoBio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
You should watch the Welcome to Autobiography video at the minimum. It will give you the basic idea for this exercise and it is less than 5 minutes long.

Introduction

Here are some basic ideas you should keep in mind as you do this exercise:

Autobiography

Make sure they don't get carried away and write a true Autobiography. It should just be an outline. Casey's Autobiography

Transitions

At their age they should have made a lot of transitions because every thing they do is new, e.g. going from one elementary school to middle school, going from for fun soccer to serious soccer. There are a lot of insights that can come from these transitions. Casey's Autobiography Insights

MyRightCareer Insights documents

These are the most important documents they will be creating during the program. They should have taken all of their findings in this exercise and placed them in the appropriate document - Be Your Best, Meaning/Passion, Economic Engine, Right Career and Whole Person. They will be accumulating their insights about each circle as they finish each exercise. This makes it easier for them to draw conclusions during the Capstone Project - which is probably quite a few weeks away. Make sure they are documenting any insights, more is better, they have reached. A lot of time all they have to do is copy the insights from documents they have already created during the exercise, e.g. there is an insights document for their Age 30 Vision. Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Experienced Adult Example

Below is an example that can help you understand the Exercise. There are more Experienced Adult examples at the end of the Examples page, which you can access from the Sub Navigation Panel on the right. Bud's Autobiography Bud's Autobiography Insights Bud's Transitions and Insights. Bud included his Transition Insights in this file.

Optional Usage by Adviser

To get started using the MyRightCareer System for your own career click on the "Experienced Adult" heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

Next Steps

Your Next Steps should be:
  • Look at an example close to your students profile. That will give you a good idea of what your student's final output should resemble.
  • See if your student needs any help while they are completing the exercise. You may be able to help them.
  • Check to see their progress via the Exercise Checklist. If they don't already have it you should suggest it as a good tool for communicating their status.
  • Once they complete this exercise, review it and then have your dialogue
  • Provide me feedback on any insights you have on the student and the Program, as well as any insights on your Adviser role.
Optionally you can:
  • Look at an Experienced Adult Example closer to your situation - they are on the Examples page.
  • Complete the exercise for your situation. click on the "Experienced Adult" heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right

Feedback

We would like your feed back on the Exercise. We would also like your feedback on the Adviser role, your interaction with your student and the support we are providing you. We would like you to take the SurveyMonkey survey in this section after you finish your work with your student. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. You can also provide feedback by sending Don an email (Don@My-Right-Career.com) or calling him at 650-400-8929.

item.title: Adviser Feedback-AutoBio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: We would like your feed back on the Autobiography Exercise. We would also like your feedback on the Facilitator role and the support we are providing you. When you get to the end of a section, hit Next to go to the next Section, at the end of a Section you can hit previous to go back one page and change your answers. Once you are comfortable with your answers hit Done and it will take you to the next Section. When you reach the last Section the system will say the Survey is completed. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. After you complete the survey please send an email to Don@My-Right-Career.com.

item.title: Begin at the End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Your assignment involves these steps: 1) Visualize Yourself at Age 30, 2) Work Backward, 3) Create a Structural Tension document, 4) document your MyRightCareer Insights, 5) Provide feedback, 6) Discuss your completed exercise with your Facilitator and 7) Become an Example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. In total they will probably take you about 4 hours. Note: If you are an experienced adult, instead of a student, visit the "Experienced Adult" page before beginning this exercise. Click on Begin at the End Checklist and you will get the pdf document that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in the Begin at the End Exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. They will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page. There are two approaches you can take to complete exercises: Short Instructions or Full Instructions. You can also use a hybrid approach in at least two different ways: 1) Use the Short Instructions for one Step and then switch to the Full Instructions on another Step if you need more help or 2) Use the Short Instructions on a Step until you need more help on that Step and then go directly to the Full Instructions on that Step for more instructions.

click on Short Instructions Approach

If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples the Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. It is basically reading a couple of sentences of instructions and using examples to do your work.

click on Full Instructions

If you would like a full set of instructions, which includes the approximately 6 minute video and instructions with multiple examples integrated into the text, then the Full Instructions Approach will work better.

item.title: Old RC Course
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the Right Career Course. The objective is to provide an overview of the Right Career concept. • Create meaning and passion • Be your best • Fuel your “economic engine” . . . . . The course has five modules. The core of the course are the 3 modules describing the three overlapping circles in the Right Career diagram above. To access each of the modules click on the paragraph headings below. This will launch Windows Media Player and a presentation by Don will begin on that topic. When the presentation finishes you can close Windows Media Player and then the Tab and you will return to this page.

  • Introduction

    This module provides an introduction to the Right Career concept and the Whole Person concept. It is about 4 minutes long.

  • Be Your Best

    This module explains how leveraging your natural strengths & personality allows you to Be Your Best. It is about 8 minutes long.

  • Meaning & Passion

    This module provides more detail on the Meaning & Passion circle and conclusions from the Success Built to Last research. It is about 6 minutes long.

  • Fuel Your Economic Engine

    This module explains the Economic Engine concept. It is about 8 minutes long

  • Summary

    This module summaries the Right Career and Whole Person concepts. It also talks about their application over the life of your career, not just at the start. It is about 7 minutes long.
    This is a self-paced course. You should begin the course with the Introduction module. After the Introduction module you should start taking the modules on the three overlapping circles in the Right Career diagram above. Each one stands alone so they could be taken at different times during the day or on different days. Obviously you should end by taking the Summary module. The total length of the Right Career course is a approximately 35 minutes. All of the modules are less than 10 minutes in length.

item.title: Step 0 - Introduction-Begin at End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Begin at the End Concept

So what is the Begin at the End approach? Robert Fritz discovered it when he studied great artists. He found they used this technique to visualize their end result of playing the piano in Carnegie hall and working backwards to their current reality of playing piano in the 4th grade. They then created structural tension between their current reality and a realistic first step. Great athletic coaches use this to visualize winning the league championship and working backwards to their current reality of having just finished a losing season. They then created structural tension between their current reality and a realistic first step. They realized it they did not make it to that first step they were not going to make it to their end result. In both cases starting with their current reality (playing piano in the 4th grade or coming off of a losing season) seems so over whelming people are often stuck and can not make any progress. The secret to these successful people is their ability to Visualize the End Result and Work Backwards and then start with some small steps.

Instructions

Welcome to the Begin at the End Exercise

Click on the link above to see a 5 minute video where Don explains your Assignment via some examples. Note: If you are using a Mac you will need to install Flip4Mac, the official Windows Media Player on the Mac, so you can play Windows Media files (.wma and .wmv) and view Windows Media content using a Web browser. You only need the Free player. Click Flip4Mac. At the conclusion of the video close the Windows Media Player, then close the page it was running in and you will return to this page.
There are two major sections to the these instructions. In the first section you will learn about the basic “Begin at the End” approach. This approach is applicable to a lot of aspects of your life besides your career. I have used it very successfully in business. It is used by many successful coaches and athletes. In the second section you will go to a unique page for each step in the Assignment: 1) Visualize Yourself at Age 30, 2) Work Backward, 3) Create a Structural Tension document, 4) document your MyRightCareer Insights, 5) Provide feedback, 6) Discuss your completed exercise with your Facilitator and 7) Become an Example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. Steps 1 through 4 will probably take you about 4 hours.

Resources to help you

Examples:One of the best ways to do this exercise is to look at how others have done the exercise. There is an exercise from Edward in all of the Assignments and it is the most complete exercise. You do not have to have your exercise be as complete as his, but it is useful as an example. The other exercises are more representative of what a typical college student would do. The examples can be found on the Begin at the End Examples page in the Sub Navigation section on the right hand side of this page. Templates: The examples also serve as templates. You can download them in their native format, mostly Word, and then use their structure, substituting your own information. They can be found on the Begin at the End Templates page in the Sub Navigation section on the right hand side of this page. Video: For those of you who learn better by listening to a presentation, instead of reading instructions, you can watch the Welcome video again.

item.title: Step 1 - Visualize Yourself at Age 30-End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Visualization Concept

You want to describe your situation at your 30th birthday. One way I suggest doing this is actually putting you at that 30th birthday party. Better yet make it a whole 30th Birthday weekend - you have the party on Saturday night and you have a bunch of your long term friends coming to visit you for the weekend. Who would those long term friends be that would come to spend the weekend. During that time what types of things would they be asking you and what types of things would you tell them about your life. What if you had not seen one of your long term friends in 5 years - how would you describe your life to him/her? I am asking you to truly visualize yourself at age 30. If you are artistic you may want to draw some pictures of your 30th birthday party and other events surrounding your 30th birthday. If you are like me and can’t draw or paint, you may want to download some clip art. With all that art you could create a Vision Board. Edward's Dream Board below was created with O Dream Board. I am sure most of you can do a more artistic job than Edward did, but it does communicate most of what he has in his Word document.
Edward's Age 30 Vision Board
Edward's End Result in Words
The O Dream Board is available for free at Oprah.com. I am not endorsing their product, just providing them as an example.
Another method of creating a Vision Board is to cut out photo's and paste them on a big poster board, You can also write and draw on the poster board.
A great resource to help you do this is a friend who knows you well. This is an exercise that lends itself to brainstorming. The two of you can spend an hour talking about your vision of yourself at age 30. Together you will come up with something better than you will by yourself.
The "Visualize the End Result" portion of the assignment will probably take you from 1 to 2 hours.

A) Visualize your Whole Person at Age 30

This exercise allows you to accomplish something very important - paint a picture, using the "Whole Person" parameters, of your life at age 30. Click on Whole Person to see a chart depicting the Whole Person concept. It was explained in the Right Career Course you took in the Prerequisites Assignment (you did take that course didn't you?). You are more than just your Career, you have all of the other elements surrounding your Career. There are a lot more things to consider when choosing your Right Career than just the jobs you will have, e.g. where you want to live, your personal relationships and your family. For example what if when you are 30 and you are only willing to be living and working in California. Or you may only be willing to work somewhere that allows you to live in San Francisco and not commute more than 30 minutes. As you later go through the process of deciding on your Right Career these Whole Person parameters will be very important to understand. By fast forwarding to age 30 you can see if you have some Whole Person issues that will end up heavily influencing your career choices. Click on Madison's End Result and you will see an example of the document you will end up creating. Here are some standard variables you can start with, but customize the list for your unique situation.

Whole Person Elements

At age 30 there will be more to your life than just your job (career). This exercise also allows you to complete the picture with other "Whole Person" parameters.
  • Personal Items, e.g.: Personal Relationship (e.g., single, living with someone or married), Immediate Family (e.g. no kids, one kid or two kids), Extended Family (e.g., emotionally close to them, estranged from them, live close by), Friends (e.g. ones from high school & college, new ones from work), Location (e.g. San Francisco, NYC, Europe, in a city, in the countryside), Residence (e.g. house, condo, apartment), Your Health (e.g. still playing soccer, better shape than now, better shape than other 30 year old's)
  • Work Related Items, e.g.: Type Organization (e.g. , Fortune 100, Early Stage Hi Tech, Non-Profit, Education), Social work environment (lots of young like minded people, serious top tier firm), Physical work environment (Google type, Wall Street type), Commute (out of home, less than 30 minutes, by train to city)
    • You can also use the categories in Whole Person Examples as a template. It provides sample sentences you could use to describe your situation at Age 30.

    Whole Person Examples

    Below are different examples of how people visualized themselves at Age 30 on some Whole Person parameters:
  • Married: This person visualized themselves being married when they were age 30. They wanted to live together two years before getting married.
  • Married and Buying a House or Condo: This person visualized themselves buying a house by the time they are 30. They also visualized themselves being married by that time as well. But they are determined to own a house, or condo, by age 30 whether or not they are married.
  • Married and Having your 1st child: This person visualizes themselves having a family with their 1st child being born when they are are 30 and other children to follow soon after. They want to have been married for two years before starting the child bearing process to ensure they have a stable marriage.

    What if you are out of College?

    Age 30 was chosen because it is far enough enough from the typical college student (e.g. Age 21 or Age 22) to allow them to remove themselves from their current situation. Age 30 is also a major milestone. If you are already out of school than you want to use an age about 7 to 10 years in the future. Carolyn is 25 and she used age 35. Click on Elizabeth's End Result to see how she visualizes herself at Age 35.

    Write Your Age 30 Vision Document

    If you click on End Result Word Template you will get a Word file with a lot of headings you can use to create your own Age 30 End Result document. If you would like to use Casey's document as your template click on Casey's End Result and you will get a Word file of Casey's End Result description. Even though Casey, Madison and Edward's examples all have a career element to them they still are mainly a definition of their Whole Person, so they are good examples for you to use.

    B) Optional Exercise - Visualize your Career at Age 30

    I know what you are thinking - "The purpose of the MyRightCareer Program is to help me identify my Right Career, so why am I being asked to visualize my career at age 30?" This is a totally optional part of this exercise. If you don't have any idea of what your career will be at age 30 then skip this part of the exercise. Here are some reasons you may want to attempt to visualize a career at age 30: 1) You might already have some ideas and the MyRightCareer Program will allow you to validate if any or all of them are good ideas, 2) You just might want to try out a career idea to see how it feels when surrounded by all the other Whole Person parameters (e.g. When I am 30 I am a lawyer working in the White House, living in Georgetown, I am so busy I barely have time to date, but this is so exciting, etc), 3) By thinking a long way out in time it might help you think of some careers you would like to be doing at that time, 4) It might help you think of some careers, or things, you would NOT like to be doing at that time (e.g. I don't want to do what my Dad has been doing for the last 30 years or I don't want to be working in an office) or 5) You might just want to describe some parameters for your career like Harry does below.

    Career Dimensions

    A simple way to think of a career is it has two dimensions: Function and Industry.
  • Function, e.g. Sales, Marketing, P/R, Finance There is a definition for this dimension and it is called Standard Occupational Classification (SOC). There are 840 Occupations and they are in Major Groups (23), Minor Groups (97) and Broad Group (461). Click on O*NET Occupations to access a Web site that will allow you to explore the vast range of occupations in a variety of ways, e.g. Job Family (groups of occupations based upon work performed, skills, education, training, and credentials), Career Clusters (occupations in the same field of work that require similar skills), Bright Outlook (occupations which are expected to grow rapidly in the next several years, will have large numbers of job openings, or are new and emerging occupations).
  • Industry, e.g. Manufacturing, Retail, Health Care, Finance, Art/Entertainment There is a definition for this dimension and it is called the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS). Every company has a NAICS. Click on 2012 NAICS and you will see a list of the 20 major industry groups. You can click on any of those major industry groups and you will then see the sub industries (maybe 30 more).
    • While almost every Occupation, or function, exists in every Industry they can be quite different depending on the Industry. For example sales in high tech is different than sales in consumer goods. Sales tends to require a lot of knowledge of the industry and customer. There are roles like Finance have more elements in common across the different industries. During the remainder of the MyRightCareer Program you will have opportunities to revisit the issue of occupations and industries. To visualize your career it might be sufficient to only choose one of the two dimensions, e.g.
  • Function - I see myself working in marketing.
  • Industry - I see myself working in the fashion industry.

    Career Visualization Examples

    Below are different examples of how people visualized their careers:
  • Multiple Majors: In some ways Edward has not really thought about a career because he has still not settled on a major. This is not an unusual problem for students, especially in today's economic climate. Edward has three different possible strategies for his major: Engineering (finishing his engineering degree and having that be his terminal major), Business (finishing his engineering degree and then immediately go into an MBA Program) and Legal (finishing his engineering degree and then immediately go to Law school). If you click on Edward's End Result you will get a pdf file of Edward vision of himself at age 30. It is not hard for Edward to visualize having a technical career given he is about to enter his senior year in engineering school and will soon graduate as an engineer. Edward is using the MyRightCareer Program to decide which of the majors is right for him.
  • Multiple Career Ideas: Carolyn is three years out college and has just turned 25. She see herself at Age 35 in one of three careers: Chief Marketing Officer in a company, Lawyer/Entrepreneur and something in the Health field. Click on Elizabeth's Work Backwards to see how she describes her three career possibilities.
  • Very General: Harry did not have a specific career in mind. Rather he has some parameters, he wanted something that: I enjoy, I am good at, I have passion for, I am helping others (makes me feel positive), I am in charge of my own destiny (no one employer can fire me), I have flexibility to take time off, I have flexibility to work in various locations, and I can work part-time if needed. Harry is going to use the MyRightCareer Program to identify a career that will meet those parameters.
  • Try out a Career Idea: Madison thinks she wants to have her own business when she is 30. That is a very general idea of a career and can have many different variations. Madison is using the MyRightCareer Program to validate if owning her own business is the right career for her.
  • A Best Guess: Casey has an idea of what she wants to do as a career. She is not sure that it is exactly her Right Career and is going to use the MyRightCareer Program to validate that choice. If you click on Casey's End Result you will get a pdf file showing Casey's description of her life at Age 30. While she is not so sure about her career choice, she does have some pretty concrete ideas about several Whole Person parameters, e.g. location and personal relationships. Casey is using the MyRightCareer Program to validate her Best Guess and if that turns out to not be true to iterate to another Best Guess.
    Remember if you don't have an idea of what career you want then just skip this part of the exercise. The most important part of this exercise is painting a picture of your Whole Person, without your career, at age 30. It will help frame your career decision later in the Program.

    C) Add your Age 30 Vision Insights

    At the end of Casey, Madison and Edward's Age 30 Vision documents you will see a section titled "Insights". In that section they provide the insights they gained by doing this exercise. For example Edward's Insights are: It was fun to think about the other elements of my life at that time. Some I have thought about, e.g. location (I have wanted to live in California, which means LA to me, for a long time), commute (I worked two summers in big cities and had to commute) and fun (with a salary I know I will be able to do a lot of fun things). But a lot of the others (e.g. personal relationship, kids, friends) I had not given much thought. This has been helpful because I was forced to put down on paper my choice of a major – which of the 3 paths do I want to take. I thought I had made that choice when I was a sophomore. It has been rolling around in my head for the last year, but I have not really been focusing on it. This let me remove myself from my immediate decision and think about what I want my work life to be when I am 30. You now need to add your own Insights at the end of your Age 30 vision document.

item.title: Step 2 - Work Backwards-End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A) Write your Work Backwards Document

Now pick one category, e.g. Financial, Personal Relationship, Family, Career. With that one category you will work backwards from your Ultimate End Result (age 30) to your Intermediate End Result #3 (age 27) to your Intermediate End Result #2 (age 24) to your Intermediate End Result #1 (age 22). You can pick any ages for your Intermediate End Results that make sense for your life. The above are just to give you a starting point. The "Work Backwards" portion of the assignment will probably take you about 1/2 to 1 hour.

Whole Person Examples

Below are some examples that use Whole Person parameters to help you write your own document. Married at Age 30 This person visualized themselves being married when they were age 30. They wanted to live together two years before getting married. Married & Buy a House at Age 30 This person visualized themselves buying a house by the time they are 30. They also visualized themselves being married by that time as well. But they are determined to own a house, or condo, by age 30 whether or not they are married. This example contains a financial analysis that works backwards from the house they visualize buying at Age 30 to what they must start doing at Age 23. Married & 1st Child at Age 30 This person visualizes themselves having a family with their 1st child being born when they are are 30 and other children to follow soon after. They want to have been married for two years before starting the child bearing process to ensure they have a stable marriage.

Career Examples

If you chose a career as an end result and want to work backwards from that end point below are some examples that will help you. Casy's example is also a template you can find on the Template page. Casey's Work Backwards is a pdf file of how Casey worked backwards from her age 30 career idea to age 22, her graduation from college. Madison's Work Backwards is a pdf file of how Madison worked backwards. Edward's Work Backwards is a pdf file of how Edward worked backwards for each of his three possible careers. On the second page you will also see how he worked backwards on his personal relationship. Elizabeth's Work Backwards is a pdf file of how Elizabeth worked backwards from age 35 to her current age (25). She also worked backwards on her Personal Life. Her document is well done and you could user her format for yours if you have multiple career ideas.

Create your own Work Backwards document

Now you need to create your own Work Backwards document.

B) Add your Work Backwards Insights

The “Work Backwards Insights” portion of the assignment will probably take you about 1/2 to 1 hour.

Whole Person Examples

At the end of the Getting Married, Buying a House or Condo and Having a Baby Work Backwards documents you will see a section titled "Insights". In that section you will find the insights gained by doing this exercise.
  • For example the "Married & Having our 1st Child" example Insights are: I have placed a lot of constraints on myself: wanting to be married for 2 years before having a baby, wanting to live together for 1 year before getting married and wanting to date seriously for 1 year before living together. This backs everything up 4 years. Then you have to add 1 year to actually have a baby and it is 5 years from the time we start dating seriously. What if it takes another year to have our 1st child, it is now 6 years. This only gives me two years to meet the right person.
  • Another example are the Insights from "Married & Buying a House": I have to do everything as if I am not going to be married. Or as if my significant other is not going to contribute. I have to start saving when I am 23 if I want to have $50K when I am 30 years old. If my significant other has been saving then we will have more than $50K. I also have to significantly increase my income from age 22 to age 30 – it doubles from $40K to $80K. If my salary doesn’t increase that fast I will end up saving less than $50K.

Career Examples

At the end of Casey, Madison and Edward's Work Backwards documents you will see a section titled "Insights". In that section they provide the insights they gained by doing this exercise.
  • For example Casey's Insights are:Working backwards was not an easy concept for me. It was easy to define where I wanted to be at age 30, even though I am not sure that is really my Right Career it is still a fun thing to think about. Then I had to think what type of person would that company want to hire as their Director of Marketing & PR. What would I have to have done before I got that job to be a good candidate? I decided they would either want someone who was already a Director, but in another small company in the same area, or they would want someone from a large well known company. I also decided they would want someone who had managed people. So I gave myself that resume. Then I had to decide how would I have gotten to be a manager in a large well known company? I assumed I would have to have worked my way up from the bottom by being very successful so I joined them out of college. It was fun and a learning experience to build up my resume this way.

Add your own Insights

Now you need to add your own Insights to your Work Backwards document. Working backwards has the benefit of introducing reality to your End Result. If your professional End Result is to be the VP of Marketing for Facebook by age 30 working backwards will probably show you that is quite a challenge. If your personal End Result is having 3 kids by the time you are 30 it will show you to not wait until you are 27 to get married.

item.title: Step 3 - Create Structural Tension-End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Now use the Structural Tension idea and create the objectives (try to keep it around 5 objectives) that would get you from your Current Reality to your Intermediate End Result #1. This portion of the assignment will probably take you about 1/2 hour.

A) Write your Structural Tension Document

If you click on Casey's Structural Tension you will get a pdf file of how Casey created a Structural Tension diagram between her Current Reality (summer between her Sophomore & Junior year) and her Intermediate End Result #1 (age 22 = graduation from college). It shows her objectives for those two years. If you click on Madison's Structural Tension you will get a pdf file of how Madison created a Structural Tension diagram. If you click on Edward's Structural Tension you will get a pdf file of how Edward created Structural Tension diagram between his Current Reality (start of his senior year) and his Intermediate End Result #1 (end of his senior year). Because of the nature of his 3 potential career paths he had to make his Intermediate End Result #1 be closer in than suggested.

B) Add your Structural Tension Insights

At the end of Casey, Madison and Edward's Structural Tension documents you will see a section titled "Insights". In that section they provide the insights they gained by doing this exercise. For example Casey's Insights are: Doing this Structural Tension exercise sure brought me back to reality. It made me focus on the fact that I am not going to be a Director unless I reach my first objective “I am an intern at either one of the top clothing design companies or top marketing professionals at one of the top clothing companies.” When I came up with the list of five things I need to accomplish in the next two years it made me realize I have a lot of hard work in front of me. But I can now see it can lead to something great. I actually don’t know if I really want to pursue that exact path but I think those 5 objectives are the right ones for me because I am going to do something in that general area. Madison had these insights: By focusing on these small steps, it will make the process of attaining my first intermediate end result a lot more manageable. I know now that I must work hard to attain these goals, in order to ultimately achieve my dream. Edward also has insights at the end of his Structural Tension document. Rather than showing them in total here is a summary: If I took either the Business or Legal path I had to make that decision by January of my senior year, i.e in only 6 months. This was because they both required me to go to graduate school and I would need to apply to either an MBA Program or a Law school by then. Even before than I need to be doing preparation work on those two paths. I was clearly behind in making my career decision. Now you need to add your own Insights to your Structural Tension document.

item.title: Step 4 - MyRightCareer Insights-End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

There are five MyRightCareer Insights files, one for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram: "Be Your Best", "Meaning & Passion", "Fuel Your Economic Engine" and "Right Career". There is another for the Whole Person. Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise. It is better to write down as many insights as you can, even if you don't think they are exactly relevant. It is easy to forget things in a long program.
These files are the most important files you are creating. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.

Examples

MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Create your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

Templates for these files can be found on the Begin at the End Templates page. You can use these templates to create your own files and begin filling out your insights. You are only adding insights for the Begin at the End exercise. One of the simplest ways of doing this is to copy/paste from the files you created in this exercise. Error on the side of including too much information in the MyRightCareer Insights files. It will be easier to delete this information later than to go back to this exercise and try to recreate it when you are working on your Capstone Project.
Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Be sure to add insights to each of the documents:
Keep these five files somewhere you will not lose them. You are going to adding to them as part of each exercise.

item.title: Step 5 - Discuss with your Adviser-End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Now it is time to discuss your results with your Adviser/Facilitator. You may have been communicating with them along the way so they may already know some of what you have done, e.g. you might have shared you Age 30 Vision. But assuming you have not shared anything here are the suggested items to share and discuss:

A) Discuss Content Issues

These first items are content oriented issues:
  • Age 30 Vision Document: (If you are currently 25 then your Age 30 Vision will probably be an Age 35 Vision)
  • Work Backwards: Age 22 Intermediate End Result #1: (This is assuming you are currently an undergrad and you will graduate at age 22).
  • Structural Tension: Age Now vs. Age 22 Structural Tension Document: What are you going to focus on in the next few months that will move you closer to where you want to be upon graduation.
  • MyRightCareer Insights Documents: This is the most important set of documents you have to discuss. They should have taken all of their findings in this exercise and placed them in the appropriate document - Be Your Best, Meaning/Passion, Economic Engine, Right Career and Whole Person. They will form the foundation for the identification of your Right Opportunity in the Capstone Project.

    B) Discuss Process Issues

    These last items are process oriented issues:
  • Schedule: You now have an idea of how long it took to do one Assignment vs. the estimated time. You and your Adviser may want to revise your schedule.
  • Adviser Review Process: You have just finished your 1st review, maybe the two of you want to do it differently in the future.
  • Anything else you want to discuss: Who knows what has come up in doing this first Assignment.

item.title: Step 6 - Provide feedback-End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We would like your feedback. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. We making changes to the MyRightCareer Program and Web site in almost real time so your timely feedback is very important. Students coming after you will benefit from it.
Please email Don@My-Right-Career.com when you finish the survey.
Click here to take survey

item.title: Step 7 - Become an Example-End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Exercise Strategy

One of the purposes of the Alpha Program is to collect a group of examples to assist students who will use the MyRightCareer Program in the future. As you are witnessing the Program relies heavily on examples as the way to communicate how to do an exercise. The long term goal is to have comprehensive set of exercises: - All of the target markets: Undergraduate Students (freshman, sophomores, juniors and seniors), Graduate Students and Just Graduated - Gender Mix: maybe 60% female and 40% male, which is the typical college campus mix - Degree Discipline Mix: Career Oriented (e.g. Engineering and Business) and Academic Oriented (e.g. Liberal Arts and Sciences). Historically college graduates' disciplines are about 60% career oriented and 40% academic oriented. I plan to have the example mix probably 60% academic oriented because they are more likely to want to identify a Career than students who have already chosen a Career oriented discipline.

1) Pick a Stage Name

Your exercise will not be put on the MyRightCareer Web site using your real name. You should pick a name you would like us to use. Maybe it is one you would use if you decided to be an actor, singer, writer, etc.

2) Send your completed exercises to Don

Send all of your completed material for this exercise to Don@My-Right-Career.com: Age 30 End Result (your Vision), Work Backwards, Structural Tension and Insights. He will review it and remove anything he feels would disclose your personal identity, e.g. names of friends, high school name, college name. He will conform the file names, headings, etc to the standards used on all the other examples (if you used the templates this will not require much work). He will append your "stage name" to the front of all of the files.

3) Review and comment on Don's Exercise files

Don will send you the proposed exercise files. You should review them and suggest any changes you would like made, e.g. drop this information, reword this information.

4) Don will load your Example on the Examples page

At the minimum your example will appear on the examples page, "Woody - Just Graduated". Individual pieces of your example may be integrated into the Full Instructions.

item.title: Step 8 - Summary-End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Begin at the End: This is a chance to think beyond doing homework and going to class. A chance to think about a new world - the world beyond 17 years in school. It is a chance to fast forward to Age 30 and skip the rest of your 20's. Don't worry about how you got there. Bring in all the "Whole Person" parameters that are important to you. See your self at your 30th birthday party.
Work Backwards This is a chance to do a little reality test of your Age 30 Vision. Work backwards to Age 22 and you will have seen what milestones you need to meet to reach your Age 30 Vision.
How will it really unfold? In reality things will unfold for you in ways that different than you put down on paper in this exercise. You will take your first step and either reach your Intermediate End Result #1 or not. You will certainly reach age 22. At Intermediate End Result #1 you will then decide the right next step.
You can repeat this process at that time. You may not have the same Vision of your life at Age 30. You can work backwards once again from your new Age 30 Vision. But at some point opportunities may present themselves, or you will create them, that you never could have imagined. You will then make a decision if you should take advantage of those opportunities and your path will take a course that is very hard to predict right now.

item.title: Step 0 - Introduction-AutoBio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Autobiography Approach

In your last assignment, Begin at the End, you visualized your life at Age 30. In this assignment you are looking back at your life to see if you can gain any further insights. You will be doing this by documenting your life in a short Autobiography, in outline format. You will then look at all the Transitions you have made in your life. Using both of these you will look at the insights you can draw.

Overview

Welcome to the Autobiography Exercise

Click on the link above to see a video where Don describes the Autobiography concept and explains your Exercise via some examples. At the conclusion of the video close the Windows Media Player, then close the page it was running in and you will return to this page.
In this exercise you need to: 1) Write your autobiography & provide insights, 2) Document your transitions & provide insights, 3) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights document the insights you have gained from this exercise, 4) Provide feedback, 5) Discuss the exercise with your Facilitator and 6) Become an example.

item.title: Step 1 - Write your autobiography
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is another exercise where you can use a friend to help you. It is best to use a friend who has know you for a long time, e.g. some one you've known since elementary or middle school. After you create your Autobiography sit down and discuss the elements with your friend. I can almost guarantee they will remember important items you left out and give you some interesting insights into items you have included.
While you are going to use the outline format to write your Autobiography the tips in the Howcast video below apply equally to that form of an Autobiography. The steps they recommend can be used for your bullet point Autobiography as well as a prose Autobiography.

Autobiography Tips

Complement your written Autobiography outline with a robust Facebook Timeline. Or just include photos in your Word file. You will find looking at photos of yourself growing up will help you write the Autobiography outline.

Autobiography Structure

Here are some elements I would like you to use, but you are free to do this anyway you find easiest. Click on:
  • Casey's Autobiography
  • Madison's Autobiography
    to see a couple of examples that follow the recommended structure. - Use an Outline format. Generally you don't need to use more than one line to describe each item, e.g. "Father quit Caterpillar and bought Varna Heating & Electric"; Merging our 13 kids with Lacon's 27 kids to make our 7th grade; Winning State Baseball Championship; Being in the Junior Play; Mr. Waxler said I should be an engineer so I went to engineering school. You are not writing this so someone else can read it. You know there is a story behind each of those one line statements. When you get famous you can use this as the outline for your Autobiography and then you (or your ghost writer) can write the prose that will let the rest of us understand your life. With Word you can have as many levels of indentation as you want if that helps communicate meaning. - Have a separate page for each element of your Life Framework. Casey's has a page for Ancestors, a page for Elementary through High School and a page for College. This lets you work on them separately – adding, deleting and changing material. - Keep your Personal and Professional elements separate. For example in Edward's he has a Personal - College and a Professional - College. You could just put everything in Personal but it will help you later identifying your Right Career by having a Professional category. Examples of items that are in Edward's "Professional - College" are: Summer Job at Detroit Edison, Founding College Newspaper and Managing construction of Fraternity Homecoming Display.

    Autobiography Approach

    Here is a tops down approach for writing your autobiography: - High Level First, start with a high level version. Don’t try to put down detail until you get the overall structure in place. Now you have an outline and can fill in details. This is the way writing coaches suggest a book be written.
  • Family: Parents & Siblings for sure Maybe Grandparents or Uncles/Aunts, or Cousins if they influenced you
  • Elementary School, Middle School (6th, 7th & 8th), High School (9th, 10th, 11th & 12th)
  • College: Freshman, Sophomore, Junior, Senior
    - Put in some Detail Second, put in some detail so you have the start of your autobiography, e.g. on the professional side you want some detail below high school and college, while on the personal side you may want to have some level of personal detail on all of them. - Drill Down Third, pick a few areas and drill down in them. You will gain insights just by what areas you choose to dive down into (they show your interests). This is not about writing down everything that has happened in your life. - Summary: You probably don’t want to have the same level of detail for every area. In the past one mistake I have seen people make is just starting to write and running out of steam about half way through. They ended up with way too much detail on the early parts of their life. One person did an elaborate history of their very large family. In retrospect they realized it was not going to be valuable but they found writing the history very interesting.

    Insights Approaches

    Here are are different ways to help you gain some insights into your autobiography.

    Look for Themes

    Below are some different ways of gaining insights from your autobiography taken from the book "What Now" by Laura Fortgang:
  • "Golden Threads" : Take a look at any "Golden Threads" that may run through your life, e.g. - Interests, e.g. environment, politics, technology - Kinds of roles, e.g. leader, follower, avoid getting involved - Cultures, e.g. small organizations, large organizations, non profits - Behavior, e.g. left tasks/groups/classes just as they got challenging, stayed put rather than take a risk, looking for next challenge - Lack of an element, e.g. lack of leadership (always behind-the-scenes), lack of outside activities (always only academic)
  • "Interrupted Dreams": See if you have any "Interrupted Dreams", e.g. things you put on hold because of being consumed by academics or sports. Maybe you just never got around to doing it. Examples might be: - Early interest in music - Competition between writing and sports, where sports won, but you still have the passion for writing.
  • "Driving Motivators": Do you have any "Driving Motivators" that are rooted in the past that not longer serve you, e.g. - Susan: worked three times harder than anyone (job, marriage, mother): driven by getting pregnant at 17 & given up college scholarship: Driving Motivator - vowed to beat the odds of not going to college. But she no longer had to prove herself, she had done that long ago. - Tom: give you shirt off his back, gave away his ideas, help people who weren’t ready to change: Driving Motivator – guilt because his family always had everything. He could now realize he did not have to take the responsibility for his family's success. - Mason: everything was because “he should do it” - the message he received from his family all the time. Did he still have to do things because he felt he had to please his family or could he start doing things that meant something to him.

    Try these Prompts

  • Don't Want to Do: If you can't think of anything you want to do, how about thinking of some things you know you don't want to do. Most people can come up with things they don't want to do more easily than they can identify what they want to do. Part of Edward's Autobiography was working for four summers with his father as an apprentice plumber and electrician. He also worked on a crew paving country roads one summer. During those 5 years he would work on farms from time to time. He knew he was not good at practical activities and should not pursue a trade. Instead he needed to do some more intellectual.
  • Born to Do: Do you feel compelled to do something because of family traditions or patterns? Harry was raised in a family where both parents were social workers. His father was a Professor of Social Work. He called his mother an idealist who often did things for others. In his definition of what he wanted to do when he was thirty one of the things he said was "I want to do something where I am helping others because it makes me feel positive." He also often organized social outings for others, e.g. ski trips.
  • Others said you should do: Is there a common theme of what others have said you should be doing with your life, e.g. you have the mind of a lawyer, you should use you musical talents, all of the family has gone into medicine? Edward was always expected to be the responsible person, the one upon whom the group could depend. Especially in high school he was expected to be the "adult". His mother was a teacher and as the principal said one time "we expect more from you Edward". That expectation stayed with him in college.

    Write your Autobiography Insights

    You can write your insights as either a separate document as Edward and Casey did.
  • Casey's Autobiography Insights
  • Edward's Autobiography
    Or you can incorporate your Insights into your Autobiography by providing the insights as you are writing about each stage of your life as Madison did:
  • Madison's Autobiography
    Or you can incorporate your Insights into your Autobiography by placing them at the end of the document.

item.title: Step 2 - Document your transitions-Autobio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You have to decide what qualifies as a major enough Transition to make it in this document. When I think of a major transition I look at the difference between the beginning state (the “from”) and the ending state (the “to”). I see it as major when there is a lot of difference in how you live your life, e.g. - Moving Homes (with your parents): once, twice, more - From home in high end town to college in old inner city - Changing Schools: public elementary to private middle & high school - Changing High School to College: small to large, public to private, private to public - Changing Sports Teams: While in high school, high school to college, while in college - Parents getting Divorced - New Blended Family - Popular to Unpopular - Normal student to Leader - Service worker to internship - Worker to manager

A) Transitions & Major Transitions documents

Here is a simple way to create a Transitions document. Make a copy of your Autobiography and name it XYZ-Transitions.doc. Now go through the document highlighting all of the items in red you feel have been a transition for you. If you believe there have been other Transitions you have not captured with this approach write them at the end of the document. To create a Major Transitions document you take the items you believe to be major and make them Bold. If you now print out a copy of the document you will have your Transitions document, which is your entire Autobiography, with some items in red and others in Bold red. This should provide you with a lot of insights into your life.
Click on Casey's Transitions & Insights to see an example of that approach.

B) Transition Insights

You could have made a lot of transitions in your life already, as laid out earlier. Each one of those transitions could provide some insights that could contribute to one of your four MyRightCareer Insights files: - Moving Homes (with your parents): Maybe you have moved several times in your life, what did you learn from that. Maybe you only moved once before going to college, but that was either great or terrible. - From home in high end town to college in old inner city: Unfortunately a lot of the older, very good schools, are "on the wrong side of the tracks". This may be the first time you have not lived in an upscale community. - Changing Schools: Maybe you went from a large public elementary school to a small private middle school. Or from a small private middle school to a large public high school. - Changing Schools: Maybe you went from a large public high school to a huge public college. Or from a small private high school to a private college that is still dramatically larger than your high school. - Changing Sports Teams: Maybe you went from a friendly local soccer team to a competitive college prep team with kids from all over the area. - Changing Sports Teams: Maybe you went from being a star on your club soccer team to being on the bench on your college soccer team. - Parents getting Divorced: Maybe your parents got divorced and your life changed dramatically. - Blended Family: Maybe your divorced mother got remarried and you now have a half sister and half brother around your age. - Popular to Unpopular: Maybe you suddenly were no longer part of the "In" group. - Normal student to Leader: Maybe you became the President of your class and people treated you differently.
You can write your insights as either a separate document as Edward did.
Click on Edward's Transitions Insights to see how he formatted his Transition insights.
What he did was make each of his major Transitions a bullet in the Autobiography outline and then put a insight comment indented below the Major Transition.
Or you can incorporate your Insights into your Transitions document by placing them at the end of the document as Casey did. She wrote three paragraphs. I realized the major academic transitions have been the hardest for me. I went to an all girls middle school where I had to make new friends and I was only around girls was hard for me to adapt too. Similarity, when I went to my large public high school, I had to transition back to being in a co-ed environment that wasn’t as creative or free as my small private all girls’ middle school. I was lucky to find a great group of girls who I love with all my heart. Both transitions helped me prepare for the biggest one yet, moving all the way to the east coast for college where I only see my family and home friends every few months. It is very different on the east coast and I learned that you have to be outgoing if you want to make friends and meet people. While these transitions have been difficult, they have helped me attain traits which I am most proud of today (my outgoing personality, optimistic attitude, being able to adapt to a new environment).

item.title: Step 3 - Add to MyRightCareer Insights-AutoBio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

If you remember from the previous exercises, there are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Opportunity" and one for "Whole Person". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise.
