By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.

Examples

These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey's examples above. Be sure to add insights from this exercise to each of the documents: - Be Your Best: From looking at your Autobiography you should have been able to identify some natural strengths and indications of your natural personality. Have you ever dedicated yourself to one activity, e.g. soccer or theater, and become really good at it. Do people tell you that you are outgoing? - Meaning & Passion: You most likely have had some passions in your life as of now. Do you love theater, sports? Are you involved in any political activities. It doesn't mean those are the ones you will have going forward, but it is important to document them. - Fuel your Economic Engine: Can you tell if your current economic standard of living is higher or lower than the one you probably will be able to afford when you are age 30? If your parents live in an expensive home and work in high paying jobs it is doubtful you will be able to do that by age 30. But is that your expectation? Have you worked to pay your expenses or have your parents always paid all your expenses? - Right Career (s): Maybe you have always wanted to be a jet pilot, Don did. Maybe when you were younger you wanted to be a coach. Even if you don't want to have those as a career now, write them down because they provide some insights into your thinking at that time. Do you have multiple ideas now that you have looked back over your life? They don't have to be realistic or even things that will survive further analysis. Write them down because they provide insights into your thought process. - Whole Person: Most of your Autobiography probably goes into the Whole Person file. At this age your life so far has been about you as a Whole Person. Have you grown up in an upscale community? Are your parents well off? Have you traveled a lot growing up? Because of those things do you expect to live in a style like you were raised? Is your community very liberal/conservative? How does your extended family influence the type of world in which you want to live? Did you grow up in a place you can't imagine ever leaving, e.g. California, New England or the South.

item.title: Step 5 - Provide feedback-AutoBio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We would like your feed back on the Autobiography Exercise. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. After you complete the survey please send an email to Don@My-Right-Career.com.
Click here to take survey

item.title: Step 4 - Discuss with your Adviser-AutoBio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Now it is time to discuss your results with your Adviser/Facilitator. You may have been communicating with them along the way so they may already know some of what you have done. But assuming you have not shared anything here are the suggested items to share and discuss:

A) Discuss Content Issues

These first items are content oriented issues:
  • Autobiography Insights: This is a key document to discuss.
  • Autobiography: This is a backup to the Insights. Remember it was not really written to be read so you will probably have to add some context for them.
  • Major Transitions Insights: Another key document to discuss
  • Major Transitions: This is a backup and probably should be shown.
  • MyRightCareer Insights Documents: This is the most important set of documents you have to discuss. You should have taken all of your findings in this exercise and placed them in the appropriate document - Be Your Best, Meaning/Passion, Economic Engine, Right Career and Whole Person. This is the first time you will have added insights to an existing document so it is important to see how your knowledge is growing.

    B) Discuss Process Issues

    These last items are process oriented issues:
  • Schedule: You have now done four exercises. You may want to revise your schedule.
  • Adviser Review Process: You have just finished your fourth review, maybe the two of you want to do it differently in the future, or you now have a process that works for both of you.
  • Anything else you want to discuss: Who knows what has come up in doing these two exercises.

item.title: Step 6 - Become an example-AutoBio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is the same process we used in the Begin at the End Exercise.

A) Send your completed exercises to Don

Send all of your completed material for this exercise to Don: Autobiography, Transitions and Insights. He will review it and remove anything he feels would disclose your personal identity, e.g. names of friends, high school name, college name. He will conform the file names, headings, etc to the standards used on all the other examples (if you used the templates this will not require much work). He will append your "stage name" to the front of all of the files.

B) Review and comment on Don's Exercise files

Don will send you the proposed exercise files. You should review them and suggest any changes you would like made, e.g. drop this information, reword this information.

C) Don will load your Example on the Examples page

He will add these examples to your section on the Examples page that was created in the Begin at the End exercise. Individual pieces of your example may be integrated into the Full Instructions. As Don gets more examples he will use examples he feels do a good job explaining key ideas. Your example may be used on one exercise and then not again for two exercises.

item.title: Step 7 - Summary-AutoBio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In the Begin at the End exercise, you should have picked up some insights about your Right Career from visualizing your life at Age 30. This exercise, looking back over your life and your ancestors lives, gives you a different perspective.
These two views of your life should give you some insights into what you can “Be Best At - your natural strengths & personality”, what has “Meaning & Passion” for you, what influences your "Economic Engine" and maybe some ideas of what you might find interesting (or found in the past) as your Right Career. They can also provide insights into your Whole Person, i.e. the parts of your life outside of your career, e.g. where you want to live, if you want to be married and the social aspects of work.

item.title: Short Instructions-AutoBio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples this Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine.

that have occurred in your life. Casey's example is: Casey's Transitions & Insights where Transitions are shown in Red and Major Transitions are show in Bold Red. item.title: Short Instructions-Begin at End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples this Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. The Full Instructions are listed in the Sub Navigation panel on the right. You can always open one of them up if you want more help. There are also additional examples on the Examples page.

0) Introduction

So quickly what is the Begin at the End approach? Robert Fritz discovered it when he studied great artists. He found they used this technique to visualize their end result of playing the piano in Carnegie hall and working backwards to their current reality of playing piano in the 4th grade.
If you want to learn more about the Begin at the End approach visit Step 0 - Introduction

1) Visualize yourself at Age 30 and Provide your Insights

This exercise allows you to accomplish something very important – paint a picture, using the “Whole Person” parameters, of your life at age 30. You are more than just your Career, you have all of the other elements surrounding your Career. There are a lot more things to consider when choosing your Right Career than just the jobs you will have, e.g. where you want to live, your personal relationships and your family.
No Career Visualized Example: Madison's End Result
As an option you can add a vision of your career at Age 30. It might be a general idea, a range of alternatives or something very specific.
Career Visualized Example: Casey's End Result
Out of School Example: Carolyn's End Result. If you are already out of school than you want to use an age about 7 to 10 years in the future. Carolyn is 25 and she used age 35.
If you click on End Result Word Template you will get a Word file that has a list of variables you can use to describe your life at Age 30. The variables are similar to the ones in the two examples above.

2) Work Backwards and Provide your Insights

Now pick one category, e.g. Financial, Personal Relationship, Family, Career. With that one category you will work backwards from your Ultimate End Result (age 30) to your Intermediate End Result #3 (age 27) to your Intermediate End Result #2 (age 24) to your Intermediate End Result #1 (age 22). You can pick any ages for your Intermediate End Results that make sense for your life. The above are just to give you a starting point.
No Career Visualized Example: Married at Age 30
Career Visualized Example: Casey's Work Backwards Casey's Age 30 End Result includes her vision of a career and this Work Backwards addresses the career aspect of that vision.
If you click on Casey's Work Backwards you will get a Word file of how Casey worked backwards from her age 30 career idea to age 22, her graduation from college.

3) Create a Structural Tension document

Now use the Structural Tension idea and create the objectives (try to keep it around 5 objectives) that would get you from your Current Reality to your Intermediate End Result #1.
Career Visualized Example: Casey's Structural Tension
If you click on Casey's Structural Tension you will get a Word file of how Casey created a Structural Tension diagram between her Current Reality (summer between her Sophomore & Junior year) and her Intermediate End Result #1 (age 22 = graduation from college).

4) Document your MyRightCareer Insights

These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Personality, Interests, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How will you Measure Your Life and Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how she has added insights with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights
To find Word templates for these files go to the Templates page. Once you use the templates and enter your Begin at the End insights into each of the five files, store them some place you won't lose them. You will be adding to them as part of each Exercise.

5) Discuss your Results with Your Adviser

Discuss the output of Steps 1, 2, 3 & 4 above.

6) Provide your Feedback

Click on Step 6 - Provide Feedback

7) Become an Example

Send your completed exercises to Don.

-8) Summary

item.title: Accomplishments
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

In this exercise you need to: 1) Create a list of accomplishments, 2) Create a list of 3 to 10 major accomplishments you really enjoyed doing, 3) Create a list of 2 to 3 accomplishments you did not enjoy doing, 4) Document the insights you gained from the exercise (both enjoyed doing and didn't enjoy doing), 5) Provide feedback, 6) Discuss your completed exercise with your Facilitator and 7) Become an Example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. Steps 1 through 4 will probably take you about 2 hours. Note: If you are an experienced adult, instead of a student, visit the "Experienced Adult" page before beginning this exercise. If you click on Accomplishments Checklist you will get the pdf document that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in the Autobiography Exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. They will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page. There are two approaches you can take to complete exercises: Short Instructions or Full Instructions. You can also use a hybrid approach in at least two different ways: 1) Use the Short Instructions for one Step and then switch to the Full Instructions on another Step if you need more help or 2) Use the Short Instructions on a Step until you need more help on that Step and then go directly to the Full Instructions on that Step for more instructions.

click on Short Instructions Approach

If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples the Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. It is basically listening to a 5 minute video and using examples to do your work.

click on Step 0 - Introduction

If you would like a full set of instructions, which includes the same 5 minute video and instructions with multiple examples integrated into the text, then the Full Instructions Approach will work better.

item.title: Short Instructions-Accomp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples this Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine.

0) Introduction

If you want to see a short video where Don explains this Exercise via some examples click on Step 0 - Introduction

1) Create a list of all of your accomplishments

Casey's example is: Casey's Autobiography Click on All Accomplishments Template This is a Word file with the outline for an All Accomplishments document. If you look at the Don or Casey examples you will see they basically used this same outline. The Accomplishments she really enjoyed are in Bold Blue and ones she didn't enjoyed are in Bold Red. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on Step 1 - List of all of your accomplishments in the Sub Navigation Panel on the upper right.

2) Create a list of your Top Accomplishments

This should be a list of 3 to 10 accomplishments you really enjoyed doing and 2 to 3 accomplishments you did not enjoy doing. Casey's example is: Casey's All Accomplishments List - Top Highlighted This is a subset of her All Accomplishments list, just the ones she really enjoyed (Bold Blue) and the ones she didn't enjoyed (Bold Red). If you want to see the Full Instructions click on Step 2 - List of Top Accomplishments in the Sub Navigation Panel on the upper right.

3) Document the insights you gained from the exercise

Document the insights you have gained from this exercise. Casey's example is: Casey's Accomplishments Insights If you want to see the Full Instructions click on Step 3 - Document the Insights in the Sub Navigation Panel on the upper right.

4) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights

Document the insights you have gained from this exercise. These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises except Economic Engine: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories and Drivers. From these examples you can see how she has added insights with every exercise. You are only adding your insights for this exercise. Click on the links below to see the documents. Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on Step 4 - Add to your MyRightCareer Insights in the Sub Navigation Panel on the upper right.

5) Discuss your Results with Your Facilitator.

Discuss the output of Steps 1, 2, 3 & 4 above. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on Step 5 - Discuss your Results with Your Facilitator in the Sub Navigation Panel on the upper right.

6) Discuss with your Career Advisory Board.

Now is time to discuss the results of your first two Assignments, Begin at the End and Look at the Past (Autobiography and Accomplishments), with your Career Advisory Board. At the minimum you need to send them your four MyRightCareer Insights files from your Accomplishments exercise: Be Your Best, Meaning & Passion, Economic Engine and Right Career. You only need to send them the files from your Accomplishments exercise because they are cumulative files and includes your insights from the Begin at the End, Autobiography and Accomplishments exercises. For each area, e.g. Be Your Best, you should have a dialogue about what you have discovered about yourself relative to that element in the Right Career Venn diagram. It is suggested you send them more than those four files and if you want to see the Full Instructions click on Step 6 - Discuss with your Career Advisory Board in the Sub Navigation Panel on the upper right. You should proceed with the next exercise while you are having discussions with your Career Advisory Board. Due to schedule conflicts it could take several weeks to complete this step and you can be working on the next exercise in parallel.

7) Provide your Feedback

Click on Feedback to access the SurveyMonkey survey for a student.

-8) Become an Example.

Send Don your completed exercises. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on Step 8 - Become an Example in the Sub Navigation Panel on the upper right.

9) Summary

item.title: Adviser Guidance-Accomp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
You should watch the Welcome to Accomplishments video at the minimum. It will give you the basic idea for this exercise and it is less than 5 minutes long.

Introduction

Here are some basic ideas you should keep in mind as they do this exercise:

List of All Accomplishments

Encourage them to truly think of all of their accomplishments, even if they don't think they relate to their future career decision. Casey's All Accomplishments List

List of Top Accomplishments

Ensure they identify accomplishments they really enjoyed doing. And that they also created a couple of accomplishments they did, but didn't enjoy doing. Casey's All Accomplishments List - Top Highlighted Casey's Top Accomplishments

Document the Insights

This may be the first time they broke their accomplishments into "I really liked doing this" and "I didn't enjoy doing this". If they were driven to build a list of accomplishments for their college application, whether they liked them or not probably didn't matter. This should provide some insights. Casey's Accomplishments Insights

MyRightCareer Insights documents

These are the most important documents they will be creating during the program. There is one document for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram. They will be accumulating their insights about that circle as they finish each exercise. This makes it easier for them to draw conclusions during the Capstone Project - which is probably several weeks away. Make sure they are documenting any insights, more is better, they have reached. Probably all they have to do is copy their insights from Step 3 to each of the MyRightCareer Insights files, as appropriate, and then add some more comments. Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Experienced Adult Example

Below is an example that can help you understand the Exercise. There are more Experienced Adult examples at the end of the Examples page, which you can access from the Sub Navigation Panel on the right. Bud's All Accomplishments List Bud's Top 7 Accomplishments List

Optional Usage by Adviser

To get started using the MyRightCareer System for your own career click on the "Experienced Adult" heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

Next Steps

Your Next Steps should be:
  • Look at an example close to your students profile. That will give you a good idea of what your student's final output should resemble.
  • See if your student needs any help while they are completing the exercise. You may be able to help them.
  • Check to see their progress via the Exercise Checklist. If they don't already have it you should suggest it as a good tool for communicating their status.
  • Once they complete this exercise, review it and then have your dialogue
  • Provide me feedback on any insights you have on the student and the Program, as well as any insights on your Adviser role.
Optionally you can:
  • Look at an Experienced Adult Example closer to your situation - they are on the Examples page.
  • Complete the exercise for your situation. click on the "Experienced Adult" heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right

Feedback

We would like your feed back on the Exercise. We would also like your feedback on the Adviser role, your interaction with your student and the support we are providing you. We would like you to take the SurveyMonkey survey in this section after you finish your work with your student. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. You can also provide feedback by sending Don an email (Don@My-Right-Career.com) or calling him at 650-400-8929.

item.title: Step 1 - List of all accomplishments
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: You need to create a list of Accomplishments from elementary school to today. Below are examples of how Casey and Edward documented their Accomplishments: Casey's All Accomplishments List Edward's All Accomplishments List One way to figure out your Accomplishments is to print out your Autobiography. Then go through each segment of your life and try to remember the Accomplishments you had for that period. You will probably find some of the entries in your Autobiography are Accomplishments. A simple way to organize these Accomplishments is to use the basic outline from your Autobiography. There is a template for that, click on All Accomplishments Template.

item.title: Step 2 - List of Top Accomplishments
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In this Step you need to decide two things about your list of Accomplishments: - Those you really liked doing - Those you didn't like doing, but still did Normally you put Accomplishments on your resume that you know other people will find impressive. It doesn’t matter if you enjoyed doing them or not. You are looking for all the things that will sell you to others. You are looking for the things that are “hot” at this moment in time. You are creating a special resume for that target company. You clearly will probably have Accomplishments on your resume that you did not enjoy doing, we all do. But you would not openly say you didn't enjoy doing it, which we are going to do here.

A) Narrow List Down to Top Accomplishments

A simple way to identify which are which is to make a copy of your All Accomplishments list file and append the word Top to the end of the file name, e.g. John-AllAccomplishments_Top.doc. Then highlight the ones you liked doing in Blue and the ones you didn't like doing in Red. Click below to see Casey and Don's examples: Casey's All Accomplishments List - Top Highlighted
Edward's All Accomplishments List - Top Highlighted

B) Really Liked Doing

Now make another pass through that file and mark the ones you Really Liked Doing in Bold Blue. Identify from 3 to 7 Accomplishments you Really Liked Doing. It is important to identify those Accomplishments you really liked doing for at least two reasons. First, you need to see these are different from the other Accomplishments. Second, this will help you identify Skills you really like using. Both of these insights will help you not only identify your Right Career but will help you perform better because when you are doing things you enjoy doing.

C) Didn't Like Doing

Now make another pass through that file and mark the ones you Didn't Like Doing in Bold Red. We all perform tasks we don't like doing. That might be the definition of school. But you will find the same thing happens in work. It is valuable to identify those things you really don't like doing so you can avoid them if possible. When you get to the next Step, Insights, you will be asked to identify the Glass Half Full for these Accomplishments you didn't like doing. Most likely some good came of them.

D) Run it by a Close Friend

This is another exercise where you can use a friend to help you. Use the same friend who helped you with the Autobiography exercise. After you create your list of Accomplishments (You really liked Doing & Didn't like Doing) sit down and discuss that list with your friend. They will probably have a different view of which ones should be marked as Bold Blue and Bold Red. They will probably also give you some insights you can use in Step 3.

D) Top Accomplishments List

Now you are going to create a document that only has your Accomplishments you really liked doing (Bold Blue) and you didn't like doing (Bold Red). The simplest way to do that is to create a copy of the AllAccomplishments_Top file and name it TopAccomplishments. Then go in and delete every Accomplishment that is not either Bold Blue or Bold Red. Click below to see Casey and Edward's examples: Casey's Top Accomplishments
Edward's Top Accomplishments

item.title: Step 3 - Document the Insights-Accomp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In this Step you need to document the insights you have gained from creating a list of your Accomplishments, deciding which ones you really liked doing and which ones you did not like doing. We suggest your Insights document have three sections: - General - Liked - Didn't Like I suggest you write the last two sections first and then see if there are some insights you can fit into either of those two categories, which you can then place in the General category. If you find every Insight is General that is fine too. Most likely you will end up with at least some "Didn't Like" Insights, as well as General Insights. Here are Casey and Edward's Accomplishment's Insights: Casey's Accomplishments Insights Edward's Accomplishments Insights

A) Really Liked Doing

Look at all the Accomplishments you labeled Bold Blue and see what insights you can draw from those. There may be some themes that run through those Accomplishments. Maybe they have changed from Middle School to High School and then again in College. If your schools were dramatically different, e.g. a small all girls middle school to a large co-ed public high school, that could impact your Accomplishments. What insights did you gain as to your natural strengths. Did the Accomplishments you like create any feeling of passion within you?

B) Really Didn't Like Doing

We all have to do things we don't like doing. But often we can not avoid doing them. If you want to be a great basketball player you are going to have to do a lot of running and maybe you hate just running. You have probably heard the Glass Half Full analogy. Take the one or two things you have identified you didn't like doing (the Glass Half Empty) and write what positive things came from that Accomplishment (Glass Half Full). Maybe you really hate math, but had to take quite a bit of it. The Glass Half Full part might be that you learned how to work hard and do well in a subject that is not a natural strength for you. It showed you that it is possible to "tough" it out when you have no choice.

item.title: Step 4 - Add to MyRightCareer Insights-Accomp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

If you remember from the previous exercises, there are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Opportunity" and one for "Whole Person". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.

Examples

These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey's examples above. Be sure to add insights to each of the documents: - Be Your Best: Does an Accomplishment point to a natural strength. Does your natural personality become obvious when you see the types of Accomplishments you gravitate towards. - Meaning & Passion: In that group of Accomplishments you Really Liked Doing do you see a Passion for something? - Fuel your Economic Engine: Does any Accomplishment provide clues as to how you are going to earn the income to support your economic desires? - Right Opportunities: Would you like to repeat any of those Accomplishments over and over again, e.g. writing articles for a living? - Whole Person: Are some of those accomplishments not career oriented, e.g. sports? Are there things that give you an idea of your Whole Person in those accomplishments?

item.title: Step 7 - Provide feedback-Accomp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We would like your feed back on the Accomplishments Exercise. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. After you complete the survey please send an email to Don@My-Right-Career.com.
Click here to take survey

item.title: Step 5 - Discuss with Adviser-Accomp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A) Introduction

Now it is time to discuss your results with your Adviser/Facilitator. You may have been communicating with them along the way so they may already know some of what you have done, e.g. you might have shared some of your Major Accomplishments. But assuming you have not shared anything here are the suggested items to share and discuss:

B) Discuss Content Issues

These first items are content oriented issues:
  • Top Accomplishments Use the full list, annotated with the Bold Blue (ones you really liked doing) and Bold Red (ones you didn't like doing). This will allow you to have a discussion as to why you picked the Bold Blue and Bold Red Accomplishments our of the Total List. It will also allow you to discuss the total list.
  • Accomplishments Insights: They will be very interested in this document.
  • MyRightCareer Insights Documents: This is the most important set of documents you have to discuss. You should have taken all of your findings in this exercise and placed them in each of the four documents. There are four of these - Be Your Best, Meaning/Passion, Economic Engine and Right Opportunities. This is the third time you will have added insights to an existing document so it is important to discuss how your knowledge is growing. You and your Facilitator can see if any patterns are developing.

    C) Discuss Process Issues

    These last items are process oriented issues:
  • Schedule: You have now done five exercises. You and your Adviser/Facilitator may want to revise your schedule.
  • Adviser/Facilitator Review Process: You have just finished your 5th review, maybe the two of you want to do it differently in the future, or you now have a process that works for both of you.
  • Anything else you want to discuss: Who knows what has come up in doing these three exercises.

item.title: Step 8 - Become an Example-Accomp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is the same process we used in the Autobiography exercise.

A) Send your completed exercises to Don

Send all of your completed material for this exercise to Don: All Accomplishments, Top Accomplishments and Accomplishments Insights. He will review it and remove anything he feels would disclose your personal identity, e.g. names of friends, high school name, college name. He will conform the file names, headings, etc to the standards used on all the other examples (if you used the templates this will not require much work). He will append your "stage name" to the front of all of the files.

B) Review and comment on Don's Exercise files

Don will send you the proposed exercise files. You should review them and suggest any changes you would like made, e.g. drop this information, reword this information.

C) Don will load your Example on Examples page

He will add these examples to your section on the Examples page that was created in the Begin at the End exercise. Individual pieces of your example may be integrated into the Full Instructions. As Don gets more examples he will use examples he feels do a good job explaining key ideas. Your example may be used on Exercise #2 and then not again until Exercise #4 and #5.

item.title: Templates-Accomplishments
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

On this page are two templates you can use. At the top is a template for the All Accomplishments document. At the bottom of the page is the Autobiography Checklist which allows you to keep track of the status of the sub-exercises in the Exercise.

Template

All Accomplishments: All Accomplishments Template This is a Word file with the outline for an All Accomplishments document. If you look at the Don or Casey examples you will see they basically used this same outline.
Top Accomplishments: There is no template for this. The simplest way to create this document is to highlight your Top Accomplishments, the ones you liked doing and the ones you didn't like doing, in your All Accomplishments document. Then you can make a copy of that document and delete all the ones that are not highlighted.
Accomplishments Insights: There is no template for this. If you create a separate Insights document consider using your Accomplishments structure as the organizing mechanism for your insights. Both Casey and Don used that approach. You can also put your insights as the end of your Accomplishments document or your Top Accomplishments document

Checklist

If you click on Accomplishments Checklist Template you will be able to down the Excel file that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in this exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. Both of you can get the file from this Templates page.

File Naming

You should save any file you down load on your computer. Then create another copy with your name appended on the front of that file. You can then fill in your own information in that new file. If you someway screw up that file you can download the template again and not overwrite the one with your data. This way you may be able to copy some of your data from your partly damaged file to the new template.

item.title: Adviser Feedback-Accomp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: We would like your feed back on the Accomplishments Exercise. We would also like your feedback on the Facilitator role and the support we are providing you. When you get to the end of a section, hit Next to go to the next Section, at the end of a Section you can hit previous to go back one page and change your answers. Once you are comfortable with your answers hit Done and it will take you to the next Section. When you reach the last Section the system will say the Survey is completed. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. After you complete the survey please send an email to Don@My-Right-Career.com.

item.title: Step 9 - Summary-Accomp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
You should now understand your Accomplishments from elementary school through college. This list will be helpful as you build your Sales Story.
From this list of Accomplishments you have also identified those that you really enjoyed doing. People generally perform better when they work at things they enjoy doing so you should pick a career that involves activities similar to these Accomplishments. Out in the Work World you may not be repeating all of these Accomplishment because they are school oriented. But the insights you have gained should provide guidance what the Accomplishments have in common that you can apply in the Work World.
You have also identified those Accomplishments you didn't really enjoy doing. Of course you would not like to have a career that involved this type of work. But hopefully your Glass Half Full exercise let you see what things you learned from these Accomplishments you can apply to your career. It should have also prepared you to take the same Glass Half Full attitude toward future task you know you will not enjoy, but have to be performed as part of your otherwise very enjoyable career.

item.title: Meaning
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

What you do must have Meaning, i.e. what you do must matter deeply to you. It’s something you’re so passionate about that you lose all track of time when you do it. In fact it may not feel like work at all. It seduces you to the point where you lose interest in everything else.
The bad news is that it’s really dangerous not to do what you love. The harsh truth is that if you don’t love what you’re doing, you’ll lose to someone who does. Your co-workers or competitors who love their work will gladly work longer hours, think about work 24/7, try more things, come up with more great ideas and get better opportunities than people who only do things for a living.
But you might say I am not driven by a vision like Gandhi or Steve Jobs. In the Success Built to Last video clip about Herb Kelleher, co-founder of Southwest Airlines, you will hear “It only has to move you”. Herb was moved by the idea of making air travel affordable to the average person, so families could get together for holidays, so small business could compete with big business. He was not trying to save the world, but this Vision had meaning to him and he built a company where it had meaning to everyone else in the company.

Exercises

This Assignment has the following exercises.

  • Success Built to Last

    • To see the detail for this exercise click on its name in the Sub Navigation section on the right. You need to watch 4 short Video Clips from the co-authors of Success Built to Last as they explain the findings of their research. People who achieve lasting success are rare and the authors set out to find out what sets them apart. Hear the author's explain how they found these people and discovered their secrets to building success that lasts. This exercise will take about 20 minutes. It is a subset of the Success Built to Last course in the Pre-Requisites Assignment. Even if you watched it there it is suggested you watch again as you now try to identify what has meaning to you.

  • Stories

    • To see the detail for this exercise click on its name in the Sub Navigation section on the right. You need to: 1) Write stories about two of your Major Accomplishments you enjoyed doing, 2) Write a story about an accomplishment you did not enjoy doing, 3) Document your Insights for each story, 4) Provide feedback, 5) Discuss your completed exercise with your Facilitator and 6) Become an Example. Each story will take about an hour to write, with another 15 minutes to add your insights. The exercise should take about 4 hours.

  • Drivers

    • To see the detail for this exercise click on its name in the Sub Navigation section on the right. You will look at what you drives you, besides money. For this exercise you need to: 1) Create the Top 30 Drivers Table, 2) Identify your Top 10 Drivers (besides money) and 3) Document the insights you have gained from identifying these Drivers, 4) Provide feedback, 5) Discuss your completed exercise with your Facilitator and 6) Become an Example. The exercise should take about 2 hours.

  • How Will You Measure Your Life

    • To see the detail for this exercise click on its name in the Sub Navigation section on the right. You will answer three basic questions. How can I be sure I will be successful and happy in my career? How can I be sure that my relationships with my spouse, my children, my extended family and close friends become an enduring source of happiness? How can I live a life of integrity — and stay out of jail? The exercise should take about 2 hours.

  • Meaning/Passion Summary

    • To see the detail for this exercise click on its name in the Sub Navigation section on the right. You will define what has Meaning to you and about what you are Passionate. For this exercise you need to: 1) You will review your MyRightCareer Meaning/Passion Insights file you have been adding to with each exercise, 2) Create your summary Meaning/Passion statement and add it to the front of your MyRightCareer Meaning/Passion Insights file, 3) Provide feedback, 4) Discuss your completed exercise with your Facilitator and 5) Become an Example. The exercise should take about 2 hours.

    Feedback

    When you have finished all of the above exercises click on Feedback in the Sub Navigation panel on the upper right.

item.title: Skills & Strengths
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This Assignment has two exercises.

  • Skills

    To see the detail for this exercise click on its name in the Sub Navigation section on the right. In this exercise you will use the O*NET System to identify the skills you really enjoy using. If you enjoy doing something you will usually do it really well, allowing you to Be Your Best. The System will then provide suggestions of Occupations that use those skills.

  • Talents/Strengths

    To see the detail for this exercise click on its name in the Sub Navigation section on the right. In this exercise you will take an assessment, StrengthsFinder 2.0, that will identify your Top 5 Talents, out of a list of 35 possible talents. It will help you identify Actions you can take to turn those Talents into Strengths.

item.title: 4 - Program Content
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The content is composed of a Prerequisite Assignment, six Insights Assignments and a Capstone Assignment. Below are short descriptions of each Assignment and the exercises within that Assignment.

Prerequisites

Before beginning the MyRightCareer Program you have to complete the Pre-Requisites exercises: Right Career Concept Overview, Program Approach, Program Content, Benefits, Adviser & Career Advisory Board and Feedback. The estimated completion time for these exercises is between 2 and 3 hours.

Insights Assignments

These are the six Assignments that will, when completed, provide the insights for the Capstone project. These will take approximately 35 to 40 hours to complete.

  • Begin at the End Assignment

    • This Assignment only has one Exercise. This will take approximately 4 hours to complete. You will learn how to throw away the constraints of today and visualize what your life could be (or you would like it to be) at age 30. The Assignment will concentrate on your Whole Person - those parts of your life outside of your career. You will learn how to use the approach of working backwards from that vision, not working forwards from your current reality. Working forwards will almost always convince you that it can't be done. But working backwards you can arrive at a milestone close to your Current Reality that is a realistic objective.

  • Look at Self Assignment

    • This Assignment has two Exercises. Completing all of the exercises will take approximately 8 hours. Personality: You will also learn about your Meyers-Briggs Personality Type and find out how you can "Do What You Are". Estimated time is 3.5 hours. Interests: You will learn what careers and occupations might be a good fit for you based on your Strong Interest Inventory assessment. You will also learn which majors are a good fit for those interests. You will look at an additional report that provides guidance from combining your Meyers-Briggs assessment and your Strong Interest Inventory. Estimated time is 3.5 hours.

  • Look at the Past Assignment

    • This Assignment has 2 Exercises. Completing all of the exercises will take approximately 6 hours. Autobiography: You will create an Autobiography, in a bullet format. This will start with a brief look at your Ancestors and then examine your life from elementary school through college. Estimated time is 3 hours. Accomplishments: You will identify your accomplishments from your early years until now. You will then identify 3 to 7 accomplishments you have really enjoyed doing and 1 or 2 you didn't like doing. Estimated time is 2.5 hours.

  • Identify Strengths Assignment

    • This Assignment has two Exercises. Completing all of the exercises will take approximately 6 hours. Skills: In the Skills exercise you identify Skills you really enjoy using. In this exercise you will use what you learned in the Accomplishments Exercise. Estimated time is 2.5 hours. Talents/Strengths: You will learn what your natural Talents/Strengths are and some Action Steps you can take to leverage them in your day-to-day life. It involves taking an assessment called StrengthsFinder 2.0. Estimated time is 3 hours.

  • Examine Meaning & Passion Assignment

    • This Assignment has four exercises. Completing all of the exercises will take approximately 10 hours. Success Built to Last: You will watch four short video clips from the author's of Success Built to Last's TV Program. You will then create a short document describing how you believe you can apply what you learned to your life. Estimated time is 1 hour. Stories: You will write a one page stories about two of the Accomplishment you have really enjoyed doing. You will write a one page story about an Accomplishment you did not enjoy doing. For all three stories you will document the insights you gained from looking at these accomplishments in more detail. Estimated time is 4 hours. Drivers: In the Drivers exercise you will identify those things, besides money, that really motivate you. Estimated time is 2 hours. Measure Your Life: You will answer three basic questions. How can I be sure I will be successful and happy in my career? How can I be sure that my relationships with my spouse, my children, my extended family and close friends become an enduring source of happiness? How can I live a life of integrity — and stay out of jail? Estimated time is 2 hours. Meaning Insights: Your assignment involves two steps: 1) Review your existing MyRC-MeaningPassion-Insights file and 2) Create a Meaning Insights Summary. Estimated time is 2 hours.

  • Understand your Economic Engine Assignment

    • This Assignment has two required exercises. The Basic Assignment (Steps 1 & 2) will take you about 2 hours, with another hour for the Insights/etc. Each of the Optional Exercises will add another hour. If you did all of the exercises this Assignment would take around 6 hours to complete. Age 30 Budget: Estimate your Age 30 Budget - Income, Taxes, Lodging, Discretionary Expenses and Non-Discretionary Expenses. You will be putting dollars to the Age 30 Vision you created in the Begin at the End Assignment. Age 22 Budget: Estimate your Age 22 Budget - Income, Taxes, Lodging, Discretionary Expenses and Non-Discretionary Expenses. This will be the budget for your first year out of college and will assume you get a professional job, hopefully in your Right Career. Optional exercises: It has three optional exercises: 3) Age 22 Non Professional Job (what if you don't get that professional job and have to support yourself), 4) Financials of Buying a House and 5) Financials of Raising a Family.

    Capstone Project

    The last Assignment is your Capstone Project that pulls everything you learned together and allows you to achieve the first two goals of the MyRightCareer Program. This Assignment has 4 Exercises. Completing all of the exercises will take approximately 15 hours. It is recommended you allow 3 weeks to complete the Capstone Project because it requires reflection to identify your Right Career (s).

  • Identify your Right Career (s) Exercise

    • You put everything you have learned about yourself together to identify your 1st Pass at your Right Career (s). It will involve all of the MyRightCareer Insights you have been accumulating in the three circles on the MyRightCareer Venn diagram: Be Your Best (leveraging your natural strengths & personality), Meaning & Passion and your Economic Engine. You will also want to take into account the insights contained in the Whole Person file. Estimated time is 6 hours.

  • Validate your Right Career Choice (s)

    • You will identify some resources (e.g Web sites, Books) that will allow you to research your target industry, target role, Whole Person Issues (e.g. where you want to live). Using the knowledge you have gained in the research you can identify people in that career area with whom you should meet (in person, on the phone or by email). They will provide even more insights that will allow you to validate if the career you identified is your Right Career. Estimated time is 5.5 hours.

  • Build a Sales Story Exercise

    • You will take the information you used to identify your Right Career and build a Sales Story to convince potential employers you are the Right person for your Right Career. Estimated time is 2.5 hours.

  • Create a Follow-on Plan Exercise

    • You will also create a Follow-on Plan so you don't lose the momentum you have generated during the Program. The length of the plan will depend on your situation, e.g. Casey’s is a 2 year plan, while Edward's is only a 9 month plan. You might want to take the Follow-on Plan back to your school Career Center (some times it is called the Career Development Center or Career Services) and get their help in implementing it. Estimated time is 1.5 hours.

item.title: Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

In this exercise you need to: 1) Take the Myers-Briggs and Strong Interest Inventory assessments, 2) Create the "Do What You Are" report, 3) Create your Personality Insights, 4) Perform a Self Assessment of your Myers-Briggs Type, 5) Validate your Meyers-Briggs Type, 6) Create your Career Insights, 7) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights document the insights you have gained from this exercise, 8 Provide feedback, 9) Discuss the exercise with your Facilitator and 10) Become an example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. In total the first seven steps will probably take you about 4 hours. Note: If you are an experienced adult, instead of a student, visit the "Experienced Adult" page before beginning this exercise. If you click on Personality Checklist you will get the pdf document that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in the exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. They will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page. There are two approaches you can take to complete exercises: Short Instructions or Full Instructions. You can also use a hybrid approach in at least two different ways: 1) Use the Short Instructions for one Step and then switch to the Full Instructions on another Step if you need more help or 2) Use the Short Instructions on a Step until you need more help on that Step and then go directly to the Full Instructions on that Step for more instructions.

click on Short Instructions Approach

If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples the Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. It is basically very short instructions (a few sentences) and using examples to do your work.

click on Full Instructions

If you would like a full set of instructions with multiple examples integrated into the text, then the Full Instructions Approach will work better.

item.title: Short Instructions-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples this Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. The Full Instructions are listed in the Sub Navigation panel on the right. You can always open one of them up if you want more help. There are also additional examples on the Examples page.

0) Introduction

Personality type is such a critical ingredient in career satisfaction because it helps people identify four of the most important features that make us who we are: how we get energy, take in information, make decisions and organize our world. And while every individual is certainly unique – we all have different genes, parents, backgrounds, etc. – people of the same personality type have a tremendous amount in common, especially with regards to what makes them satisfied and successful in their work.
If you want to watch a 7 minute video explaining the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator or a video where Don explains your Exercise via some examples, click on Step 0 - Introduction in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

1) Take the Myers-Briggs and Strong Interest Inventory assessments

To understand how to access the appropriate Web site go to Step 1 - Take the Myers-Briggs and Strong Interest Inventory assessments. You will only be using the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator Career Report in this exercise. Casey's report is: Casey's Myers-Briggs Report

2) Create the "Do What You Are" report.

To understand how to access the appropriate Web site go to Step 2 - Create the "Do What You Are" report. Casey's example is: Casey's "Do What You Are" Report

3) Create your Personality Insights

Create a Personality Insights document using information from your “Do What You Are” report. The Insights document should mirror the sections in the Do What You Are document.
Casey's example is: Casey's Personality Insights.
Personality Insights Word template This is a Word file with the outline for the Personality Insights document.

4) Perform a Self Assessment of your Myers-Briggs Type.

To perform this self assessment use this MBTI Self Assessment template This is an Excel file with four pages - one for each of the four elements in the Meyers-Briggs Type (e.g. Extroversion vs. Introversion). There are nine characteristics for each element and you place an X next to the ones you feel represent you.
Casey's example is: Casey's Meyers-Briggs Self Assessment

5) Validate your Meyers-Briggs Type.

Look at the two types of insights you gained in the previous Step: Self-Assessment Worksheet and Outside Feedback. Now create a document where you provide your logic for what your “true” personality type should be.
Casey's example is: Casey's Validated MBTI
There is no template for this step.

6) Careers Insights.

You have now validated your Myers-Briggs Type, e.g. Casey decided she was an ENFJ, even though her self assessment said she was an ENFP. So the next step is to analyze what that means from a career viewpoint. To do that you will use your “Do What You Are” report. It has sections that provide you information about: What you need in a career for it to be satisfying; Some satisfying career fields and jobs for your Myers-Briggs type (examples of careers many people of your Type find satisfying) and How to use your personality type strengths to conduct a successful job search.
Casey's example is: Casey's Career Insights
Career Insights Word template

7) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey’s examples below.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

8) Discuss your Results with Your Adviser.

Discuss the output of Steps 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 & 7 above.

9) Provide your Feedback

Click on Feedback to access the SurveyMonkey survey.
10) Become an Example. Send Don your completed exercises.

11) Summary

item.title: Step 0 - Introduction-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Personality Type Concept

Discover Your Personality Type Video

Click on the link above to watch a 7 minute video explaining the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator. The video was created by PersonalityDesk, the people from whom you will take the Myers-Briggs assessment. If you feel you already know what the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator is you don't need to watch this video.
Personality type is such a critical ingredient in career satisfaction because it helps people identify four of the most important features that make us who we are: how we get energy, take in information, make decisions and organize our world. And while every individual is certainly unique – we all have different genes, parents, backgrounds, etc. – people of the same personality type have a tremendous amount in common, especially with regards to what makes them satisfied and successful in their work. Quite simply, when we using our natural, inborn personality type preferences – our gifts – (yes, you are born with a type!), people feel energized, motivated and satisfied. Conversely, when we are doing tasks that are not natural to us, it drains our energy and we are less successful. The only factor that remains constant over the entire course of a person’s lifetime is their Personality Type.

Exercise

Welcome to the Personality Exercise

Click on the link above to see a video where Don explains your Exercise via some examples. At the conclusion of the video close the Windows Media Player, then close the page it was running in and you will return to this page.
In this exercise you need to: 1) Take the Myers-Briggs and Strong Interest Inventory assessments, 2) Create the "Do What You Are" report, 3) Create your Myers-Briggs Type Insights, 4) Perform a Self Assessment of your Myers-Briggs Type, 5) Validate your Meyers-Briggs Type, 6) "Do What You Are" Analysis & Insights, 7) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights document the insights you have gained from this exercise, 8 Provide feedback, 9) Discuss the exercise with your Facilitator and 10) Become an example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. In total the first seven steps will probably take you about 4 hours.

item.title: Templates-Personality
